title: How to get a full-ride scholarship as a transfer international student - Quora
tags: College and University Scholarship and Fellowships

response.answer_text: It might theoretically be possible, but it’s certainly not probable. The vast majority of educational institutions focus their merit-based financial aid on students entering as freshman. In addition, public schools hardly ever use their limited financial aid budgets to help international students, even those who enter as freshmen. Instead, international students are expected to pay full tuition and expenses as a way of stabilizing the university’s bottom line. Finally, for both public and private schools, any financial aid that is reserved for transfer students often goes to those students who (for financial or other personal reasons) have completed their first two years at a community college. In summary, it’s possible that some college or university somewhere has a full merit aid scholarship available for an international student entering as a transfer, but the likelihood is vanishingly small.

Get in touch with Harvard, Yale, M.I.T., Princeton, and Amherst. They are the only U.S. universities that have need-blind/full-need programs for foreign students. You won’t find a full-ride at a public (taxpayer-supported) university unless you can somehow manage to get an athletic scholarship.
Transfer students - citizens and internationals alike - are not first in line for scholarships - unless they are transferring in from two year community colleges.
